Who down votes bubbles?

The vortices are seen, are made visible here, due to thin-film interference effects. The beautiful colors, like motor oil on water. Thin-film interference color effects are in turn due to very small continuously dynamic variations in the thickness of the thin film floating on the surface of the water, in this case, a thin film of soap. (Or tiny variations in the thickness of a thin film of motor oil floating on a puddle.) Variations in thickness of the film so small that from one location to another nearby, but of a different color, the thickness differences are on the order of wave lengths of visible light. Really small!!

So, this means that, if the swirling structures made visible on the surface by the soap film are due to, or reflective of, systematic patterns of heat flow within the water of the bubble, those heat flows I think must be systematically varying the thickness of the soap film in some true way so that we "see" the heat flows. Looks like this is true too because the swirling vortices seem to appear predominantly on the top of the bubble. The top is the part of the bubble to which the warmest water, which gets heated only at the bottom of the bubble (i.e,. from the metal can), would probably rise. And once there, give up some of its heat to the surrounding air. Swirling would be from faster-moving and slower-moving regions of the bubble's surface, which I think would in turn stretch in paces, and compress in others, the amount of soap in the film which would indeed vary it's thickness.

i am a little upset. i started out liking PBS content on youtube but then started being appalled by some of the lack of attempted objectivity and a certain insertion of personal values into content (yes, it was Idea Channel and Game/Show). i liked PBS content because it tried to present as many sides as possible and expanded my ability to see different points of view, i was very disappointed when particular morals and values were starting to be considered correct and others were condemned.

i have become very wary of PBS content ever since, which is a shame because i feel they do a better job than most (yes, i am talking about news groups like Fox News). but these channels have discarded a certain level of honesty to the point that i have unsubscribed to their channels. i don't enjoy the right, and the left is just about as distasteful at this point.

i appeal to Physics Girl to keep true to her original content, which i have mostly enjoyed. please don't abandon your style and don't include your own personal ideas of idealized society into your content. i feel i get preached to enough and i really like your tongue-in-cheek approach to rigorous scientific topics. you provide relaxed content on serious topics, if you want to make an editorial then i think it would be best served on another channel (like Veritasium did) because this works very well.

+physics girl Hey just wanted to reach out and thank you for making these videos. I am a 7th grade science teacher. This one in particular I saw right before I had an inquiry activity in my class. My inquiry activity was to make a 50cm bubble using a limited supply of materials. Anyways the students had great excitement before they went out to do this because of your video.

On another note, You have one of the few science channels that has a "girl" hosting it. I try to show your videos when they fit into what I am teaching in class, as I know kids need to completely change their mindset on stereotypes of scientists. You are young and female. I hope you keep this channel up and keep inspiring, and I will be showing your videos in my class. Thanks again.
